<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a suspended metre ruler and determine the weight of the metre ruler.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 908, 137]]<|/det|>
Refer to Fig. 1.1. Do **not** change the position of the loops of thread attached to the force meters.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 144, 885, 358]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 371, 532, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 144, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 402, 180, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 402, 846, 420]]<|/det|>
Move the 1.50 N load to a distance \(d = 40.0 \text{cm}\) from the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the ruler.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 418, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
Raise or lower one clamp slightly, if necessary, so that the metre ruler is as near to horizontal as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 464, 777, 483]]<|/det|>
Read the value \(F_{\mathrm{x}}\) on force meter X and the value \(F_{\mathrm{y}}\) on force meter Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 494, 920, 514]]<|/det|>
<form>F<sub>X</sub> = ............................................................ N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 524, 920, 544]]<|/det|>
<form>F<sub>Y</sub> = ............................................................ N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 555, 826, 575]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value \(W_{\mathrm{x}}\) using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{x}} = F_{\mathrm{x}} + F_{\mathrm{y}} - k\), where \(k = 1.50 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 618, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
<form>W<sub>X</sub> = ............................................................ N

<label>(ii)</label>

Ensure that the metre ruler is as near to horizontal as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 660, 138]]<|/det|> Read, and record in Table 1.1, the value \(F_{\mathrm{x}}\) on force meter X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 724, 168]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure for \(d = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 180, 541, 198]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 211, 640, 364]]<|/det|>

Start the axes at the origin (0, 0). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 384, 439]]<|/det|> Draw a best-fit straight line. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 445, 752, 841]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 863, 920, 881]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 69, 730, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 260, 120]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 125, 819, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 310, 532, 329]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 342, 144, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 342, 180, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 342, 707, 361]]<|/det|> Measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 371, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ........................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 403, 180, 421]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 403, 734, 422]]<|/det|> Describe **one** technique for ensuring that this reading is accurate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 495, 176, 514]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 495, 504, 514]]<|/det|> Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 511, 579, 530]]<|/det|> Place the thermometer into the water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 542, 920, 578]]<|/det|> In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-watch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 588, 787, 607]]<|/det|> Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30 s until \(t = 270 \text{s}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 621, 539, 638]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 650, 665, 928]]<|/det|>
\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(\theta /\mathrm {}^{\circ }\mathrm {C}\)
0
30
60
90
120
150
180
210
240
270
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[908, 925, 932, 942]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 186, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 117, 556, 149]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{90}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 787, 181]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 181, 487, 199]]<|/det|>
Include the unit for the cooling rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 255, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x_{1} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 181, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the middle 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 333, 561, 365]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{90} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 378, 834, 397]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 456, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x_{2} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 489, 181, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 489, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{3}\) during the last 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 534, 564, 566]]<|/det|>
\[x_{3} = \frac{\theta_{180} - \theta_{270}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 579, 851, 598]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) and \(\theta_{270}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 180 \text{s}\) and \(t = 270 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 657, 920, 677]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 718, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
Use your results from (c) to describe the overall pattern of the rate of cooling of the water in the experiment. Justify your answer by reference to your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 70, 871, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate circuits containing different combinations of resistors. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 393, 121]]<|/det|> Circuit A has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 272, 137]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 658, 168]]<|/det|> **Resistor \(\mathbf{R_{p}}\) must remain in place throughout the experiment.** <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 175, 720, 395]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 411, 534, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 198, 460]]<|/det|> **Circuit A** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 144, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 185, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 473, 339, 492]]<|/det|> Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 475, 523]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 3.1: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 702, 539]]<|/det|> • the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across terminals P and Q <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 535, 448, 552]]<|/det|> • the current \(I\) in the circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 566, 336, 584]]<|/det|> Open the switch. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 597, 541, 615]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 628, 771, 733]]<|/det|>
\(V/V\)\(I/A\)\(R/\Omega\)
circuit A
circuit B
circuit C

Use your values of \(V\) and \(I\) and the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 780, 918, 798]]<|/det|> [1]

A student determines the resistance of \(\mathsf{R}_1\). He uses a variable resistor in circuit B to control the current and draws a graph of \(V\) against \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 806, 494]]<|/det|>
Briefly explain **one** advantage of using a variable resistor to control the current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 479, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the refraction of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 918, 182]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 918, 228]]<|/det|>
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 425, 259]]<|/det|>
Concentration is measured in \(\text{g} /\text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 470, 290]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 398, 320]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 868, 351]]<|/det|>
• samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 556, 367]]<|/det|>
• a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 223, 399]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 457, 429]]<|/det|>
• list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 789, 445]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 485, 460]]<|/det|>
• state the key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 918, 491]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 603, 507]]<|/det|>
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 515, 856, 745]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 758, 530, 775]]<|/det|>
